speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: SCENE II. The French camp.

speaker: KING HENRY V
text_entry: Enter the DAUPHIN, ORLEANS, RAMBURES, and others

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: The sun doth gild our armour; up, my lords!

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Montez A cheval! My horse! varlet! laquais! ha!

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: O brave spirit!

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Via! les eaux et la terre.

speaker: ORLEANS
text_entry: Rien puis? L'air et la feu.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Ciel, cousin Orleans.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Enter Constable

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Now, my lord constable!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Hark, how our steeds for present service neigh!

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Mount them, and make incision in their hides,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: That their hot blood may spin in English eyes,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: And dout them with superfluous courage, ha!

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: What, will you have them weep our horses' blood?

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: How shall we, then, behold their natural tears?

speaker: RAMBURES
text_entry: Enter Messenger

speaker: Messenger
text_entry: The English are embattled, you French peers.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: To horse, you gallant princes! straight to horse!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Do but behold yon poor and starved band,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And your fair show shall suck away their souls,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Leaving them but the shales and husks of men.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: There is not work enough for all our hands;

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Scarce blood enough in all their sickly veins

speaker: Constable
text_entry: To give each naked curtle-axe a stain,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: That our French gallants shall to-day draw out,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And sheathe for lack of sport: let us but blow on them,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: The vapour of our valour will o'erturn them.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: 'Tis positive 'gainst all exceptions, lords,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: That our superfluous lackeys and our peasants,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Who in unnecessary action swarm

speaker: Constable
text_entry: About our squares of battle, were enow

speaker: Constable
text_entry: To purge this field of such a hilding foe,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Though we upon this mountain's basis by

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Took stand for idle speculation:

speaker: Constable
text_entry: But that our honours must not. What's to say?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: A very little little let us do.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And all is done. Then let the trumpets sound

speaker: Constable
text_entry: The tucket sonance and the note to mount;

speaker: Constable
text_entry: For our approach shall so much dare the field

speaker: Constable
text_entry: That England shall couch down in fear and yield.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Enter GRANDPRE

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Why do you stay so long, my lords of France?

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Yon island carrions, desperate of their bones,

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Ill-favouredly become the morning field:

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Their ragged curtains poorly are let loose,

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: And our air shakes them passing scornfully:

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Big Mars seems bankrupt in their beggar'd host

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: And faintly through a rusty beaver peeps:

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: The horsemen sit like fixed candlesticks,

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: With torch-staves in their hand; and their poor jades

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Lob down their heads, dropping the hides and hips,

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: The gum down-roping from their pale-dead eyes

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: And in their pale dull mouths the gimmal bit

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Lies foul with chew'd grass, still and motionless;

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: And their executors, the knavish crows,

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Fly o'er them, all impatient for their hour.

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: Description cannot suit itself in words

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: To demonstrate the life of such a battle

speaker: GRANDPRE
text_entry: In life so lifeless as it shows itself.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: They have said their prayers, and they stay for death.

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: Shall we go send them dinners and fresh suits

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: And give their fasting horses provender,

speaker: DAUPHIN
text_entry: And after fight with them?

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I stay but for my guidon: to the field!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: I will the banner from a trumpet take,

speaker: Constable
text_entry: And use it for my haste. Come, come, away!

speaker: Constable
text_entry: The sun is high, and we outwear the day.

speaker: Constable
text_entry: Exeunt
